titleStmt.title: Chavez Ravine:From a Home to Home Plate
titleStmt.author: S. Gao
L. Zezza
J. Sotelo

bibl.title: Name of the archival collection, Institution

div.p: In 1959 in a hilly alcove known as Chavez Ravine, the construction of today’s Los Angeles landmark, Dodger Stadium, began. That same year, a little girl and resident of the ravine, was photographed standing on her family’s property. Features contorted, she holds a sign of protest that reads, “Can you buy three lots and two houses for $10,000”, which directly addresses the city of Los Angeles. Compositionally, the image not only documents a time and place, but also functions as an artistic statement: captured directly in the center of the Polaroid frame, the little girl becomes both a literal central figure, and a figurative heroine in the battle for her community lost to corporate modernization.
